name: Cabernet Sauvignon
flavor_profile: Full-bodied, rich black currant, cedar, and tobacco notes
history: Cabernet Sauvignon is one of the most widely recognized red wine grape varieties. It has origins in the Bordeaux region of France, where it is often blended with Merlot and Cabernet Franc. Its global popularity soared in the 20th century, particularly in regions like California, where it produces bold and complex wines.
food_pairing: Pairs well with red meat dishes such as grilled steak, lamb, and beef stew. Also complements hard cheeses like aged cheddar and gouda.

name: Chardonnay
flavor_profile: Buttery, with notes of green apple, citrus, and vanilla
history: Chardonnay is one of the most widely planted white grape varieties globally. Its origins trace back to the Burgundy region of France. It gained international fame for its versatility and ability to produce a wide range of wine styles, from crisp and unoaked to creamy and oaky.
food_pairing: Pairs well with creamy pasta dishes, roasted chicken, seafood like lobster or crab, and creamy cheeses like brie and camembert.

name: Merlot
flavor_profile: Soft and velvety, with flavors of plum, black cherry, and herbs
history: Merlot is a red wine grape variety with origins in the Bordeaux region of France. It gained popularity for its smooth texture and approachable flavors. Merlot-based wines are often blended with Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc.
food_pairing: Pairs well with roasted chicken, grilled pork, mushroom dishes, and medium-aged cheeses like gouda and gruyere.

name: Pinot Noir
flavor_profile: Delicate, with red fruit flavors like cherry, raspberry, and cranberry
history: Pinot Noir is one of the oldest grape varieties in the world, with origins dating back to the Burgundy region of France. It is known for its delicacy and transparency, often reflecting the terroir where it is grown. Pinot Noir has gained international acclaim, particularly from regions like Burgundy, Oregon, and New Zealand.
food_pairing: Pairs well with grilled salmon, roasted duck, mushroom risotto, and soft cheeses like brie and camembert.

name: Sauvignon Blanc
flavor_profile: Crisp and refreshing, with notes of green apple, lime, and grass
history: Sauvignon Blanc is a white wine grape variety originating from the Bordeaux region of France. It has gained popularity for its vibrant acidity and aromatic qualities. Sauvignon Blanc is widely planted in regions like New Zealand, California, and the Loire Valley in France.
food_pairing: Pairs well with seafood dishes like oysters, shrimp, and ceviche. Also complements salads, goat cheese, and dishes with tangy sauces.

name: Syrah (Shiraz)
flavor_profile: Full-bodied, with dark fruit flavors like blackberry, plum, and pepper
history: Syrah, also known as Shiraz in some regions, has origins in the Rhone Valley of France. It is one of the darkest red wine grape varieties, known for its bold flavors and rich texture. Syrah is also widely planted in regions like Australia, where it is known as Shiraz.
food_pairing: Pairs well with grilled meats such as lamb chops, barbecued ribs, and steak. Also complements dishes with bold flavors like spicy stews and smoked meats.

name: Riesling
flavor_profile: Aromatic, with flavors of peach, apricot, and honey, often with a hint of petrol
history: Riesling is a white wine grape variety originating from the Rhine region of Germany. It is known for its aromatic qualities, high acidity, and ability to express terroir. Riesling wines range from bone-dry to intensely sweet, depending on the ripeness of the grapes at harvest.
food_pairing: Pairs well with spicy dishes like Thai curry, smoked salmon, pork chops, and spicy Asian cuisine. Also complements blue cheeses and fruit-based desserts.

name: Grenache
flavor_profile: Medium-bodied, with flavors of red fruit, spice, and herbs
history: Grenache is a red wine grape variety originating from the Aragon region of Spain. It is widely planted in the Rhone Valley of France and other warm climate regions around the world. Grenache-based wines are known for their ripe fruit flavors and soft tannins.
food_pairing: Pairs well with Mediterranean dishes like grilled vegetables, ratatouille, and lamb kebabs. Also complements dishes with savory herbs and spices.

name: Malbec
flavor_profile: Full-bodied, with flavors of blackberry, plum, and cocoa
history: Malbec is a red wine grape variety originating from the Cahors region of France. It gained prominence in Argentina, where it produces deeply colored and robust wines. Malbec is known for its dark fruit flavors and firm tannins.
food_pairing: Pairs well with grilled meats like steak and ribs, barbecue dishes, and hearty stews. Also complements aged cheeses and dishes with earthy flavors.

name: Sangiovese
flavor_profile: Medium-bodied, with flavors of red cherry, plum, and dried herbs
history: Sangiovese is a red wine grape variety originating from the Tuscany region of Italy. It is the primary grape used in wines such as Chianti and Brunello di Montalcino. Sangiovese-based wines are known for their bright acidity, firm tannins, and savory flavor profile.
food_pairing: Pairs well with tomato-based pasta dishes, pizza, grilled sausages, and aged cheeses like pecorino. Also complements dishes with herbs like rosemary and thyme.

name: Tempranillo
flavor_profile: Medium to full-bodied, with flavors of red fruit, leather, and tobacco
history: Tempranillo is a red wine grape variety originating from the Rioja region of Spain. It is one of Spain's most important grape varieties and is used to produce a range of wines, from joven to reserva. Tempranillo-based wines are known for their versatility and ability to age.
food_pairing: Pairs well with Spanish tapas like chorizo, grilled vegetables, and paella. Also complements roasted meats and dishes with smoky flavors.

name: Zinfandel
flavor_profile: Full-bodied, with flavors of ripe berry, black pepper, and spice
history: Zinfandel is a red wine grape variety with disputed origins, though it is primarily associated with California, USA. It produces robust and fruit-forward wines with moderate tannins. Zinfandel is known for its versatility, as it can be made into a range of styles, from dry to sweet.
food_pairing: Pairs well with barbecue dishes like ribs and pulled pork, spicy Mexican cuisine, and hearty pasta dishes. Also complements aged cheeses and chocolate desserts.

name: Chenin Blanc
flavor_profile: Versatile, with flavors ranging from crisp green apple to honey and apricot
history: Chenin Blanc is a white wine grape variety originating from the Loire Valley of France. It is known for its versatility, as it can produce wines ranging from bone-dry to intensely sweet. Chenin Blanc is also planted in regions like South Africa and California.
food_pairing: Pairs well with seafood dishes like shrimp scampi, sushi, and oysters. Also complements spicy Asian cuisine and dishes with tropical fruit.

name: Gewürztraminer
flavor_profile: Aromatic, with intense floral notes, lychee, and spice
history: Gewürztraminer is a white wine grape variety originating from the Alsace region of France. It is known for its highly aromatic qualities, with intense floral and exotic fruit notes. Gewürztraminer produces wines ranging from dry to sweet.
food_pairing: Pairs well with spicy dishes like Thai curry, Indian cuisine, and Mexican mole. Also complements dishes with strong flavors like foie gras and blue cheese.

name: Viognier
flavor_profile: Aromatic, with flavors of peach, apricot, and honey
history: Viognier is a white wine grape variety originating from the Northern Rhone region of France. It is known for its highly aromatic qualities, with intense floral and fruit notes. Viognier produces wines with medium acidity and a rich texture.
food_pairing: Pairs well with seafood dishes like crab cakes and lobster, chicken dishes with creamy sauces, and spicy Asian cuisine. Also complements dishes with tropical fruit flavors.

name: Sémillon
flavor_profile: Rich and honeyed, with notes of ripe apricot, honey, and beeswax
history: Sémillon is a white wine grape variety originating from Bordeaux, France. It is known for its ability to produce full-bodied, complex wines with high alcohol content. Sémillon is often blended with Sauvignon Blanc to make Bordeaux Blanc and is also used to produce sweet wines like Sauternes.
food_pairing: Pairs well with rich seafood dishes like lobster, crab, and scallops. Also complements creamy sauces and dishes with tropical fruit flavors.

name: Zweigelt
flavor_profile: Medium-bodied, with flavors of red berries, black pepper, and spice
history: Zweigelt is a red wine grape variety created in Austria in the early 20th century. It is a cross between St. Laurent and Blaufränkisch. Zweigelt produces fruity and approachable wines with moderate tannins and acidity.
food_pairing: Pairs well with roasted chicken, grilled sausages, and pork tenderloin. Also complements dishes with savory herbs and spices.

name: Vermentino
flavor_profile: Crisp and aromatic, with flavors of citrus, green apple, and floral notes
history: Vermentino is a white wine grape variety widely planted in Italy, particularly in regions like Sardinia and Liguria. It is known for its vibrant acidity and aromatic qualities. Vermentino produces fresh and lively wines with citrus and mineral notes.
food_pairing: Pairs well with seafood dishes like grilled fish, shrimp scampi, and seafood pasta. Also complements salads, vegetable dishes, and light cheeses.

name: Carmenere
flavor_profile: Medium to full-bodied, with flavors of dark fruit, bell pepper, and spice
history: Carménère is a red wine grape variety originating from Bordeaux, France. It was widely planted in Bordeaux until the phylloxera epidemic in the 19th century nearly wiped it out. Today, Carménère is primarily associated with Chile, where it produces deeply colored and aromatic wines.
food_pairing: Pairs well with grilled meats like steak and lamb, spicy Mexican cuisine, and hearty pasta dishes. Also complements dishes with smoky flavors.

name: Albariño
flavor_profile: Crisp and aromatic, with flavors of stone fruit, citrus, and saline minerality
history: Albariño is a white wine grape variety originating from the Galicia region of Spain. It is known for its crisp acidity and intense aromatics. Albariño is widely planted in the Rías Baixas region, where it produces refreshing and seafood-friendly wines.
food_pairing: Pairs well with seafood dishes like grilled shrimp, ceviche, and seafood paella. Also complements dishes with briny flavors like olives and capers.

name: Garnacha (Grenache)
flavor_profile: Medium to full-bodied, with flavors of red and black fruit, spice, and herbs
history: Garnacha, known as Grenache in France, is a red wine grape variety that likely originated in Spain. It is one of the most widely planted grape varieties globally and is known for its versatility in producing both single-varietal wines and blends. Garnacha/Grenache wines are characterized by their ripe fruit flavors and soft tannins.
food_pairing: Pairs well with grilled meats, such as lamb and pork, as well as dishes with Mediterranean herbs and spices. Also complements dishes with tomato-based sauces and grilled vegetables.

name: Viura (Macabeo)
flavor_profile: Light to medium-bodied, with flavors of citrus, green apple, and floral notes
history: Viura, also known as Macabeo, is a white wine grape variety primarily grown in Spain. It is often used in the production of Cava, Spain's famous sparkling wine. Viura produces wines with crisp acidity and bright fruit flavors, making it suitable for both still and sparkling wines.
food_pairing: Pairs well with seafood dishes such as grilled fish and shrimp cocktail, as well as light salads and appetizers. Also complements mild cheeses and dishes with lemon-based sauces.

name: Cabernet Franc
flavor_profile: Medium-bodied, with flavors of red currant, raspberry, and green bell pepper
history: Cabernet Franc is a red wine grape variety originating from the Bordeaux region of France. It is often used as a blending grape in Bordeaux-style blends, adding aromatic complexity and structure. Cabernet Franc is also grown as a single-varietal wine in regions like the Loire Valley, where it produces wines with herbaceous and fruity characteristics.
food_pairing: Pairs well with roasted poultry, grilled vegetables, and dishes with tomato-based sauces. Also complements dishes with fresh herbs and soft cheeses.

name: Moscato (Muscat)
flavor_profile: Sweet and aromatic, with flavors of peach, apricot, and orange blossom
history: Moscato, also known as Muscat, is a white wine grape variety known for its sweet and aromatic wines. It is one of the oldest grape varieties in the world, with a long history of cultivation in regions like Italy, France, and Spain. Moscato wines are often made in a range of styles, from dry to sweet, and are prized for their floral and fruity aromas.
food_pairing: Pairs well with fruity desserts such as peach cobbler and lemon tart, as well as spicy Asian cuisine. Also complements dishes with tangy cheeses like blue cheese.

name: Barbera
flavor_profile: Medium to full-bodied, with flavors of red cherry, plum, and baking spices
history: Barbera is a red wine grape variety native to the Piedmont region of Italy. It is one of Italy's most planted grape varieties and is known for its high acidity and versatility. Barbera wines are often unoaked and fruit-forward, with vibrant acidity and soft tannins.
food_pairing: Pairs well with tomato-based pasta dishes, pizza, and roasted meats such as pork and duck. Also complements dishes with mushrooms and aged cheeses.

name: Petit Verdot
flavor_profile: Full-bodied, with flavors of dark fruit, violet, and tobacco
history: Petit Verdot is a red wine grape variety originating from the Bordeaux region of France. It is primarily used as a blending grape to add color, tannin, and structure to Bordeaux-style blends. Petit Verdot produces deeply colored and intense wines with firm tannins and bold flavors.
food_pairing: Pairs well with grilled meats such as steak and lamb, as well as hearty stews and braised dishes. Also complements dishes with rich sauces and strong cheeses.

name: Aligoté
flavor_profile: Crisp and refreshing, with flavors of green apple, lemon, and mineral notes
history: Aligoté is a white wine grape variety primarily grown in the Burgundy region of France. It is often overshadowed by Chardonnay, the dominant white grape of Burgundy, but Aligoté produces wines with high acidity and bright citrus flavors. Aligoté is also used to produce Crème de Cassis, a popular French liqueur.
food_pairing: Pairs well with shellfish such as oysters and clams, as well as light salads and appetizers. Also complements dishes with creamy sauces and soft cheeses.

name: Montepulciano
flavor_profile: Medium to full-bodied, with flavors of dark cherry, plum, and earthy notes
history: Montepulciano is a red wine grape variety native to the Abruzzo region of Italy. It is known for its juicy fruit flavors and soft tannins, making it approachable in its youth. Montepulciano wines are often characterized by their vibrant acidity and versatility with food.
food_pairing: Pairs well with Italian dishes such as pasta with tomato-based sauces, pizza, and grilled sausages. Also complements dishes with mushrooms and aged cheeses.

name: Glera
flavor_profile: Light and crisp, with flavors of green apple, pear, and floral notes
history: Glera is a white wine grape variety primarily grown in the Veneto region of Italy. It is the primary grape used to produce Prosecco, Italy's famous sparkling wine. Glera wines are known for their light and refreshing character, with lively acidity and delicate fruit flavors.
food_pairing: Pairs well with seafood appetizers, light salads, and fresh fruit. Also complements dishes with mild cheeses and light sauces.

name: Mourvèdre (Monastrell)
flavor_profile: Full-bodied, with flavors of blackberry, black pepper, and gamey notes
history: Mourvèdre, known as Monastrell in Spain, is a red wine grape variety originating from the Rhone Valley of France. It is known for its thick skins and high tannin levels, producing wines with intense color and bold flavors. Mourvèdre/Monastrell is often used as a blending grape, adding structure and complexity to wines.
food_pairing: Pairs well with grilled meats such as lamb and beef, as well as dishes with rich, savory sauces. Also complements dishes with spicy flavors and strong cheeses.
